Midas Documentation » SECTION 5: Run Control » Run Control Programs » mhttpd: the MIDAS Web-based Run Control utility » Main Status Page

Features of the Main Status Page

The Status Page is sub-divided in several parts:

  • Experiment/Date/Refresh information
  • Menu buttons
    • Run Control buttons
    • Page Switch buttons
  • Optional Script buttons
  • Manual-Trigger Buttons
  • Alias-Buttons
  • Run status information
  • Equipment information and Event rates
  • Data Logging Information
  • Last system message
  • Active Client list

These will be discussed in detail in the following sections.

mhttpd main status page showing Menu Buttons



Experiment/Date/Refresh information

The top line on the main status page above shows

  • the Experiment name ("Online")
  • the current date
  • the refresh period (Refr:600) - see note below

It is important to note that the refresh of the Status Page is not "event driven" but is controlled by a timer whose rate is adjustable through the Config button. This means the information at any given time may reflect the experiment state of up to n seconds in the past, where n is the timer setting of the refresh parameter.

Menu buttons

The top row of buttons on the main status page are the

  • Run Control buttons
  • Page Switch buttons

Run Control buttons

Depending on the run state, a single or the two first buttons on the main status page will show the possible action that can be taken, i.e.

Run Control buttons visible depending on Run State

Run Control Buttons present
(see Note below)

Run State

Action

Start

STOPPED

Start the run

Stop

RUNNING

Stop the run

Pause

Pause the run

Resume

PAUSED

Resume the run

Since Nov 2009 , the Run Buttons may be hidden (see Hide Run Buttons ),

Page Switch buttons

The Page Switch buttons on the mhttpd main status page (see example above) change the page to one of the sub-pages. The sub-pages all provide a button labelled Status, which returns to the main Status page when clicked. The purpose of each Page Switch button is explained in the following table:

The Page switch buttons can now be customized ( since Dec 2009 ) , so not all the possible Page Switch buttons may be visible on the status page for a particular experiment.

Page Switch Buttons on the Main Status Page

Page Switch Button

Explanation

ODB

This button switches to the (see ODB page), which provides access to the Online Data Base.

MSCB

This button switches to the MSCB page , which gives access to devices in a MIDAS Slow Control Bus system. (Implemented Dec 2009)

CNAF

In versions since Dec 2009 the default is that this button has been replaced by the MSCB button. If the CNAF button is needed, it must be added to the list of menu buttons.
This button switches to the CAMAC Access page . If one of the equipments is a CAMAC frontend, it is possible to issue CAMAC commands through this button.

Messages

Clicking this button opens the message page and shows the N last entries of the MIDAS system message log. The last entry is always present in the status page (see Last system message ).

ELog

This button gives access to the Electronic Log book (Elog). The Elog allows the permanent recording (i.e. in a file) of comments, messages, screen captures etc. composed by the users (see Elog page).

Alarms

Clicking this button displays the Alarm page , which shows the current Alarm setting for the entire experiment. The activation of an alarm is done through the ODB under the /Alarms tree (See MIDAS Alarm System)

Programs

This button gives access to the Programs page, which displays the status of the current programs (i.e. MIDAS applications/clients) which are or have been running for this experiment.

History

Display History graphs of pre-defined variables. The history setting has to be done through ODB under the /History (see History Logging , History page).

Config

Allows the page refresh rate to be changed. See Config page .

Help

Help button will link to the main MIDAS web documentation (i.e. this document).



Optional Buttons on the main Status page

mhttpd main Status page (part) showing optional buttons


Since Dec 2009 there may be up to three rows of buttons below the Menu buttons

  • Script (User) buttons
  • Manually triggered event buttons
  • Custom Page and Alias buttons

Prior to Dec 2009 the Custom Page and Alias hyperlinks appeared as links rather than buttons, as shown here.



Optional Script buttons

Script (or User) buttons that appear on the main status page are used to execute user-defined scripts. These buttons are defined through the optional ODB /script tree.

See

  • Defining script buttons

for details.



Manual-Trigger Buttons

See Manual Trigger .



Alias-Buttons

User-defined Alias-buttons that appear on the main status page give access to Alias pages.

  • How to create Alias-Buttons



Run status information

mhttpd status page showing Run Status information


The run status information on the main status page shows

  • current run number
  • run state
  • Alarm status
  • Restart (automatically restart run)
  • mlogger status
  • run duration

The appearance and contents of this information changes depending on the conditions. The images below demonstrate how the appearance may change when the run is in transition.

mhttpd status page showing Run Status information when the run is stopping


mhttpd status page showing Run Status information when the run is starting




Comment and Run Description

Optionally, the user can define a "comment" and/or a "Run Description" that will appear on the mhttpd main status page. This is done by creating keys "Comment" and/or "Run Description" in the Run Parameters subdirectory under /Experiment. The contents of each key will then be displayed on an extra line on the mhttpd main status page. See The ODB /Experiment tree for more information.

[local:t2kgas:S]/>ls -lt "/Experiment/Run Parameters/"
Key name                        Type    #Val  Size  Last Opn Mode Value
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Comment                         STRING  1     32    19h  0   RWD   no beam, test only
Run Description                 STRING  1     32    19h  0   RWD  28.2keV resonant energy 7Li


mhttpd main status page showing "Comment" and "Run Description" fields



Equipment information and Event rates

The mhttpd status page contains a table of Equipment information and event rates. Equipments are usually defined in frontends. Other MIDAS clients which may define Equipments include slow controls and eventbuilder clients.

mhttpd status page showing Equipment information and Event rate statistics

Monitor the Equipment variables

The "Equipment" column of this table lists the names of any defined Equipments. These appear in the order in which they are listed in the ODB /Equipment tree.

The names of the equipment in this column are hyperlinks to their respective /Equipment/<equipment-name>/Variables sub-tree. Clicking on any of the equipment links will show an Equipment page , allowing a shortcut for the user to access the current values of the equipment.


Status display of each Equipment

The "Status" column of the mhttpd status page shows the status of each equipment. It usually shows the name of the client defining that equipment, and the host computer on which that client is running, The background colour of each equipment "Status" box will also change depending on the status of the associated frontend. The usual colours are shown in the following table:

Default colour coding of Equipment status

Frontend is RUNNING and equipment is ENABLED

Frontend is MISSING

Frontend is RUNNING but equipment is DISABLED


When a run is in transition, or when a client takes a long time to respond, the status information may change to give a status report on the client. Optionally, users may program a client to send their own status reports that appear in this area of the mhttpd status page by incorporating calls to the routine set_equipment_status (see Reporting Equipment status). This routine allows the message and the status box background colour to be specified. For example, the last client in the image above (HV_SY2527) gives a Status of "OK" rather than the default client and hostname.

In versions prior to Dec 2009 , the "Status" column was labelled "FE Node" and the client status information was not shown (see Redesign of mhttpd Main Status Page ).



Event Rates

The event statistics for the current run are also shown on the main status page , in the columns labelled "Events", "Events[/s]" and "Data[MB/s]".



Number of events analyzed

In versions prior to Dec 2009 , there is an extra column labelled "analyzer" which shows the number of events analyzed (valid only if the name of the analyzer is "Analyzer").



Data Logging Information

The image below shows the information on the status page if both mlogger and lazylogger are running.

logger information on mhttpd main status page



Compare this example with the minimal status page where neither of these clients are running.


In the image above,

  • one mlogger channel (Channel 0) is active.
    Multiple logger channels can be active, in which case a line for each channel would be shown. The hyperlink "0" opens a mhttpd Logger page showing the settings information.
  • one lazylogger channel (Dcache ) is also active. Multiple lazy applications can be active, in which case multiple lines of Lazy information would be present. Clicking on the hyperlink "Dcache" opens a mhttpd Logger page showing the lazylogger settings information .



Last system message

Example of last system message on mhttpd main status page



The last system message to be received at the time of the last display refresh is displayed on the main status page (see Messaging). More messages can be viewed by pressing the Message button. This opens the Message page.



Active Client list

Example of Active client list on mhttpd main status page



At the bottom of the main status page is a list of the MIDAS clients for this experiment that are currently active. The hostname is also shown. This information is derived from the ODB /System tree .
